Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Magnetic circular dichroism of dicobalt(II) enzymes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Through this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program is funding Professor James Larrabee at Middlebury College to carry out studies of metallohydrolases using magnetic circular dichroism (MCD) spectroscopy. The five metallohydrolases that will be studied are related to health and medical problems of current importance for the society. The active sites of these enzymes are chemically similar; specifically they include two metal ions bridged by carboxylate and water (or hydroxide) ligands. The enzymes are studied by the research group of Professor Larrabee in the Co(II) form, which provides an especially strong MCD signal. One aim of the research is to improve our understanding of how substrates interact with the metal ions in the active sites. Changes in the metal environment caused by the binding of substrate analogues that function as inhibitors to the enzymes are monitored by MCD spectroscopy and provide insight into the mechanism of the enzyme. A second aim is to discover which amino acid residues in the active site are important for the function of these enzymes.

Understanding how enzymes function is of scientific interest and, in the case of enzymes implicated in disease-related biological processes, it may help with the diagnosis and treatment of the diseases. The enzymes studied by Professor Larrabee pertain to the latter category and the proposed studies are designed to advance the understanding of their mechanism. The spectroscopic and calorimetric studies described in the proposal will examine the metal binding and the electronic structure of the active sites of the enzymes. Changes in the active sites induced by interaction with substrate or substrate analogs that function as inhibitors will also be studied. The proposed research is conducted at Middlebury College by undergraduate students. Research experiences such as those undertaken by the Middlebury undergraduates are known to encourage the students to further their science education and to pursue careers in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

 

 

Enzymes are biological molecules which catalyze chemical reactions in living systems, which would not otherwise occur under mild conditions. The enzymes that were studied in this project are hydrolase enzymes that have a dimetallic active site that break bonds in substrate molecules by insertion of a water molecule. Two classes of dimetallic hydrolase enzymes were studied by the spectroscopic technique of magnetic circular dichroism (MCD) to help elucidate the mechanisms: (1) bacterial hydrolases that break down organophosphorous compounds used in pesticides and chemical warfare agents and (2) bacterial hydrolases which break down antibiotic drugs and are thus responsible for antibiotic-resistant infections. Although these two classes of enzymes have very different functions, the active sites are structurally similar.

 

All of the enzymes studied are active with a variety of transition metal ions in the active site (manganese, iron, cobalt, or zinc), but in these studies the dicobalt(II) metalloforms of the enzymes were used because cobalt(II) is an excellent spectroscopic probe in MCD studies. MCD allowed the determination of the coordination numbers of both cobalt ions and detection of any bridging ligand changes between the cobalt ions in the resting enzymes as well as the enzymes complexed with slow-reacting substrates, substrate analogs or inhibitors. The MCD results significantly contributed to our understanding of the reaction mechanisms in these enzymes.

 

 

Broader impacts

 

 

 

 

 

Human resource development: Thirteen Middlebury College undergraduates were directly or indirectly supported with this grant. Six students were hired as summer research assistants, and six students were supported during academic year research projects. Four students were co-authors on peer-reviewed scientific journal papers. Seven of these students went on to graduate studies in chemistry or biochemistry and one went on to graduate study in engineering.

 

 

Science: (1) Significant advances in our understanding of the organophosphorous hydrolase enzymes have been accomplished. These enzymes have been shown to detoxify organophosphorous compounds, which are used as pesticides or chemical warfare agents, and thus could be used in bioremediation of contaminated soils and surfaces. (2) Significant advances in our understanding of enzymes responsible for antibiotic resistance in certain bacteria have also been made. These advances may ultimately lead to alternative treatments for bacterial infections.
